keyTakeAways: Amazon Web Services (AWS) experienced a widespread outage that disrupted internet services globally, affecting social media, gaming, financial platforms, and education tools.
The outage originated in AWS’s domain name system (DNS), which converts web addresses into IP addresses, leading to widespread failure across dependent services.

Services such as Snapchat, Roblox, Fortnite, Robinhood, Netflix, Disney+, Coinbase, Signal, Amazon Ring, Alexa, and Canvas were impacted, demonstrating the deep integration of AWS into global digital infrastructure.

Educational platforms like Canvas were unable to support students and instructors, disrupting academic activities at institutions including the University of California, Riverside and Ohio State University.

Cybersecurity experts note that modern society relies heavily on a small number of tech firms (like Amazon, Google, Microsoft) for internet infrastructure, making the system vulnerable to cascading failures.
The outage is not unprecedented — AWS has had previous major outages in 2017, 2020, 2021, and 2023, showing a recurring pattern of infrastructure fragility.
Experts like Mike Chapple and Patrick Burgess emphasize that such outages are typically due to technical issues, not cyberattacks, and are resolved through standard recovery protocols within hours.
The event highlights the fragility of a technology-dependent society and the need for greater redundancy and resilience in cloud computing systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Amazon Web Services (AWS) suffered a major global outage on Monday, October 20, 2025, beginning around 3:11 a.m. Eastern time and resolving by 6 p.m. Eastern time. The root cause was traced to a failure in AWS's domain name system (DNS), which disrupted access to a wide range of online services, including social media (Snapchat, Roblox, Fortnite), financial platforms (Robinhood, Coinbase), streaming services (Netflix, Disney+), and education tools (Canvas). The outage affected users of Amazon’s own services like Ring and Alexa, and led to academic disruptions at universities such as Ohio State and the University of California, Riverside. Experts like Mike Chapple and Patrick Burgess noted that such outages are typical of a world increasingly dependent on a few major cloud providers, with recovery processes being slow and bumpy but generally manageable within hours. This event underscores the fragility of modern digital infrastructure, where a failure in one core service can cascade across countless other platforms, affecting individuals, businesses, and institutions worldwide.
title: Amazon Cloud Outage Exposes Fragility of Internet Infrastructure
